title: boris global britain remainers brexit pulling up drawbridge
story: Boris’s announcement that — once we’ve left — the UK will welcome the best and brightest science minds from around the world is a real commitment to a truly Global Britain.It marks an end to the absurd state of affairs in which we had an open door to anybody born in the EU, regardless of their talents, and were effectively forced to slam another door in the face of those who have shown themselves to be  leaders in their fields.There are still those who think that the vote to leave the EU was an  anti-immigrant vote. It wasn’t. It was a vote to take back control.And as we look towards our departure, this Government must deliver an open immigration system that welcomes those who will  contribute to the economy and  le of our great country.With a say on who comes in — and who doesn’t — we’ll be able to ensure our public services are ready for a population increase and that the supply of houses goes up as quickly as it needs to.Don’t believe the doomsayers. Once we’re free of Brussels’ grip this country can take its place back at the very top of the world. A magnet for hard-working, talented people, who can take our already successful businesses to the next level.It’s another clear reason why, no matter how messy our departure sometimes seems, and how long it is taking…Britain is still better off out.JUST when you thought Project Fear was dead, here comes the BBC to stick it on le support.We’ve had such a constant barrage of scare stories about a clean break Brexit that anybody who believed them all would have run for the hills with a decade’s worth of spam and a shotgun.This week  there have been panicked predictions of rationing and cattle culls and warnings from US economist Larry Summers — who some see as one of the architects of the  financial crisis — that we’re a “desperate” nation which can’t hope for a decent US trade deal.Given rather less fanfare by Auntie was a letter from Republican Senators pledging to deliver just that.Some comfort is that nobody’s buying it any more.The public is rapidly losing faith in the Beeb.FINALLY, it’s back.The Premier League promises to be better than ever — and this season will see the added drama of VAR. About time, too.Get your Dream Team sorted, and enjoy the season.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: paul hollywood only has himself to blame
story: Actually, Summer Monteys-Fullam ran out of the door after being told she had to sign a draconian non- disclosure agreement, vowing not to give away any details of her affair with the Bake Off dough boy.She decided to pack up all her crop tops and tight jeans and flee as fast as her lithe, -year-old legs would carry her.We are told Hollywood, , charmingly bellowed after her: “Why don’t you f*** off back on that horse you rode in on ”Not exactly the stuff of tender romance, I’m sure you will agree. But let’s be honest, I think we all knew this midle crisis of a romance would end in tears.For a start it all played out in the public eye like a soap opera, which never bodes well.Paul, who bizarrely seems to be regardedas some sort of sex symbol, has not exactly covered himself in glory when it comes to his love le.Don’t forget that back in , he cheated on ex-we Alex with his cutesy-pie American co-presenter.That was when he went to the US hoping to cash in on his Bake Off fame and attempted to build a lucrative career across the pond.The affair with Marcela ­Valladolid might have generated a lot of free publicity and media attention, but his bid for transatlantic success never took off.He came home with his tail between his legs and had to eat a great big entire humble pie to win back his we.We don’t ever know what goes on inside a marriage, but Alex took him back, possibly for the sake of their teenage son Josh.At the same time she appeared on my show to kick-start her own career as a cook.She was very good, with a no-nonsense, immensely likeable personality — and her food was delicious. She’s since become a celebrity chef in her own right.I recall that Alex brought her sheepish husband along with her that morning for her first appearance on live TV.Perhaps it was for moral support, but I reckon it was more likely to keep an eye on him. He did his best impersonation of a penitent man and they somehow managed to reheat the souffle.Of course, it didn’t last.They split up in  and that same year, Hollywood began his relationship with ex- barmaid Summer.Alex was convinced the affair began before they finally split but this was vehemently denied by both Paul and Summer.Paul and Alex, of course, are now orced. And he apparently faces an imminent court battle over cash.Alex could even end up with half her ex-husband’s ­estimated £million fortune.She is currently enjoying a holiday in France, where she was photographed looking chic, cool and effortlessly ­elegant.No one could fail to forgive her for feeling a bit smug that her ex has been so publicly dumped. After all, she had to bear her share of public humiliation over his behaviour.Meanwhile, it gets worse and worse for Paul, as inevitably there is now talk of ­Summer writing a book and appearing in a clutch of reality shows.She didn’t sign the NDA so is completely free to warble about their sex le and all sorts of potentially embarrassing revelationsshe wishes.So it looks like Paul is leaving Summer behind him and entering the autumn and winter of his le alone, with only himself to blame.I’ve just gobbled up the entire new BBC series Fosse Verdon about the hugely talented husband and we team who, among many other hits, gave us musicals Sweet Charity, Cabaret and Chicago.It’s gratying to see Broadway legend Gwen Verdon finally given the acclaim she deserves for the part she played in Bob Fosse’s success.He was a genius choreographer and director but also a notorious womaniser, chain-smoker, heavy drinker and pill popper.This series never shies away from Fosse’s sleazy side, showing how manipulative he could be – and his seduction of vulnerable young actresses and dancers is not easy to watch.We are light years from the #MeToo movement, and this series illustrates why we need it so much.Sam Rockwell plays a blinder as Fosse, but Michelle Williams is a revelation as Gwen Verdon.It’s as though the red-headed dancing star has been brought back to le.You know those stock responses you get after stating the bleedin’ obvious – about the Pope being Catholic and bears defecating in the woods.There is another one which I always thought was very callous.“Does Rose Kennedy own a black dress ”This is particularly unfeeling given the many tragedies visited upon the Kennedy clan – continuing right up to the present day.Theirs is a long litany of pain and suffering.Matriarch Rose endured the death of her eldest son Joe during World War Two, before the unimaginable ordeal of seeing two more sons publicly gunned down.First when John, as US President, was assassinated in . Then his younger brother Bobby, the former Attorney General turned senator and presidential candidate, was brutally slain in .The “Kennedy curse” has persisted through the decades.Twenty years ago, John F Kennedy Jnr, JFK’s only son, died while flying his light aircraft to the Massachusetts island of Martha’s Vineyard when it crashed into the ocean.In , Mary Kennedy, the estranged we of Robert Kennedy Jr – Bobby’s son – was found dead in her New York home, having apparently taken her own le.And this week, the family gathered for yet another tragic occasion.This time it was the funeral of Bobby’s -year-old granddaughter Saoirse Kennedy Hill, who died from a suspected overdose at the family compound in Cape Cod.Rose died in  aged .She was spared witnessing the deaths of some of the younger members of the family, including poor Saoirse.But after all she endured during her long le, she deserves a bit more respect and understanding than being the punchline to a weak joke.Whoever signed up Michelle Visage for Strictly Come Dancing deserves a pay rise.Michelle, right, one of the stars of the fabulous RuPaul’s Drag Race, will be a firecracker of an addition to Strictly. She’s sassy, sexy, ballsy and a real grafter.She has a wonderful dirty laugh and a terric outlook and she’ll seize this show by the throat.I’d have paid real money to have seen her reduce sacked former pro Brendan Cole to a whimpering jellyfish.It’s a huge shame that’s no longer a possibility, but bosses need to make sure Michelle is paired with a young, hungry dancer not afraid to take risks.There could perhaps be a chance for Kevin Clton to win two Glitterballs in a row after his success with Stacey Dooley last year.Kevin and Michelle could really burn up that dance floor and there would be no hanky panky from this loyal woman whose -year marriage to hubby David is rock solid.So no Strictly “curse”, but knowing Michelle, maybe rather a lot of Strictly cursing.Her big-heartedness remains undimmed even under the cruel shadow of Alzheimer’s, so it was no surprise that Dame Barbara Windsor used her nd birthday this week to demand more action to help fellow sufferers and their families.While other entertainers with long careers might have used their special day just to celebrate their achievements, Dame Barbara instead pleaded for us all to show compassion towards those with dementia, and for the Government to ensure more resources are made available.Barbara and her devoted husband Scott Mitchell have become ambassadors for the Alzheimer’s Society charity and have sent an open letter to Boris Johnson to sort out the care crisis that is making le so very hard for everyone affected by this disease.Now Boris might profess to being unafraid of all of the EU grandees as he tries to deliver Brexit, but he should be quaking in his boots at the prospect of the wrath of our Barbarahe doesn’t deliver vital help and money to those affected by dementia.More power to this incredible woman and how lucky she is to have Scott to take care of her because, sadly, not everyone dealing with dementia has such a devoted partner.They have both made a huge dference in raising awareness and much-needed cash.When this horrible disease is finally vanquished, and one day it must be, we will never forget the part Barbara and Scott played. Our journalists strive for title: sepsis toddler survive lost limbs
story: Brave -month-old Oliver Aisthorpe has made a miraculous recovery after doctors warned mum Abigail Wardle, , that her son wasnt going to pull through.But now, just a few weeks on, Oliver is back home and making an incredible recovery - and medics even hope he could have his first prosthetic legs fitted in a few months.Courageous Abigail has chosen to speak out about their sepsis hell in a bid to help other parents learn how to spot the signs of the killer bug that little Oliver caught through an undiagnosed throat infection.Abigail, a jewellery designer, said: Some people might feel sorry for us but I feel like the luckiest mum in the world - I still have Oliver with us - he might not have any hands or feet but he is still my smiley, brave little boy.What we went through was horrendous and I had never been so scared in my le.But Oliver was so brave that I knew I had to be brave too. I am his mum and its my job to fight for him and make him feel safe.He went from laughing and giggling to deaths door within  hours and nobody knew what was wrong with him.I dont want any other family to go through what we went through, and so I want everyone to be more aware of sepsis - families but also GPs, who sometimes dont have the specialist paediatric training available to spot it.I want some good to come out of what happened to Oliver.Abigail first took her son to an out-of-hours GP on Saturday, March , when she noticed his soft spot appeared to be sunken and she worried he was dehydrated.But she says a GP sent her home and told her to give him fluids and Calpol.But by the next day, he had deteriorated - and Abigail again took Oliver to see an out of hours GP.It happens when your immune system overreacts to an infection and starts to damage your bodys own tissues and organs.You cannot catch sepsis from another person.It happens when your body overreacts to an infection.Sepsis is sometimes called septicaemia or blood poisoning.It can be especially hard to spot in: babies and young children, people with dementia, people with a learning disability and people who have dficulty communicating.Sepsis needs treatment in hospital straight away because it can get worse quickly.You should get antibiotics within  hour of arriving at hospital.If sepsis is not treated early, it can turn into septic shock and cause your organs to fail. This is le threatening.Source: NHSDoctors discovered that the sepsis had developed from an undiagnosed throat infection - which Oliver had never shown any symptoms of.They managed to stabilise Oliver but warned Abigail thathe deteriorated they would not be able to save him.Incredibly, the little boy pulled through - and survived with no damage to his brain, but the sepsis has caused both hands and his legs to turn black and effectively die off.Medics battled to savein Olivers leg, but mum Abigail begged them to speed the operation along because she could see the leg self-amputating.She said: The limbs were heavy and uncomfortable - Oliver was miserable, I know it sounds like an odd thing for a mother to say but I was desperate for them to take them off.One day, a nurse was helping me lt Oliver from his bouncy chair back into the bed, and his leg just came away.Once he had his limbs removed, he was like a dferent child - so happy and full of le, it seemed like a relief for him.Last month, Oliver was discharged from hospital and is now getting used to le without his limbs.Abigail added: I am just so proud of Oliver.He has taken everything in his stride and is just so incredibly resilient. He makes me smile every day.Already, he is trying to work out how to roll over and play with his toys with his stumps.She added: I could have come out of the other end of this with no son, so thats what I focus on.We have our bad days, but I know that there will be better days to come.I want his story to be used to help spread awareness and teach other parents and GPs who maybe dont have specialist paediatric training, about the signs of sepsis.

Hamzah Parvez, , known as Hungry Hamzah for complaining about missing KFC takeaways while inside the Islamic State, fled Britain for Syria, aged . Five years later, the terrorist – now held by western-backed Kurdish forces – claims he never bought into IS ideology, despite spending half a decade under the brutal regime. In an exclusive prison-cell interview with the Mirror, Parvez said he was stuck between “a wall and a hard place” and unable to leave. And the family he abandoned in West London, while admitting they will “always hate what he did”, have called for him to face justice in Britain. Parvez was stripped of his citizenship, but his parents Mohammed and Riaz want it restored so he can face court here.  They also want his we and young children, one of whom is disabled, to be brought up with their family in North West London. They are believed to be in a camp in northern Syria.Riaz, , has demanded a meeting with Home Secretary Sajid Javid to discuss his case. Weeping as she was shown photos of Parvez, who has lost more than four stone in prison, talking to the Daily Mirror in Syria, she said: “I can’t believe this is Hamzah.”A relative, who asked not to be named, insisted “he has to come back”, despite blaming the stress of Parvez joining IS for causing Mohammed, , to suffer a stroke and a brain haemorrhage. She said: “He was very selfish. People treat us like terrorists and we are good, normal people. We hate what he did and will always hate what he’s done, because it’s going to affect us forever.  “That’s why it’s only fair he comes back and is punished in some type of way.” She added his family “would be very concerned”it emerged he could also face extradition to the US. The relative said he is “nowhere near as high profile” as two of the IS “Beatles” El Shafee Elsheikh and Alexanda Kotey, who were sent to America. She insisted he should face justice in Britain, not Syria or the United States. She said: “That would be really unfair because he hasn’t committed such crimes as Kotey and Elsheikh.” In a -minute interview with the Mirror, Parvez, who is being held in a secret location in Rojava, northern Syria, said IS beheading videos were good publicity, but criticised bosses for leaving him and others to carry the blame. The former police cadet said: “The leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi put into place those who call the shots.

story: NewsFarmer with land on both sides of Irish border fears no-deal Brexit will hit hardBreffni McKiernan runs a -acre site in Swanlinbar, Co Cavan, with his dad Gerry but says the uncertainty of Brexit is causing him stressShareCommentsByTrevor QuinnTanveer MannAssistant News Editor:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsBreffni McKiernan runs a -acre site in Swanlinbar, Co Cavan, with his dad Gerry "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A farmer with land on both sides of the border fears a no-deal Brexit could hit him hard.Breffni McKiernan runs a -acre site in Swanlinbar, Co Cavan, with his dad Gerry and says the uncertainty of Brexit is causing him stress. They live just km away from the frontier with the North while being surrounded by the Benaughlin Mountain in Co Fermanagh. Because of their location, the father and son duo now fear a no-deal Brexit will bring milk export taxes and border checks.Breffni told the Irish Mirror : You would [have fears] over a hard border – most definitely. Especially as I cross it five or six times a day.“I’ve heard stories about it before. [My dad] would be worried about it. What went on years ago it was torture for the people. “I don’t think it’ll come to that. I think they learnt enough years ago with the amount of people that were killed and injured. It couldn’t come down to that again.” Will a no-deal Brexit turn your le upside down  Email webnews@mirror  The dairy herd management graduate, who rents a number of fields across the border in the North, studied for two years at Ballyhaise Agricultural College before he started farming full-time. He added: “I’ve a lot of family across the border. My mother Jacinta’s from Fermanagh – only about five minutes down the road in Kinawley. “We’ve a lot of uncles and aunties down there and I’d cross the border five or six times a day maybe. “You’d hardly notice and you wouldn’t pass any dference. “My relatives would be concerned. The way the whole thing was going on and then it didn’t even happen in March and now it’s extended until October. “I think people are just fed up at this stage. Farmers obviously want some sort of a deal, but I think people are surprised by the situation.“I never thought it would happen at all and with Boris Johnson in now, I think things could change again.”Breffni believes former prime minister Theresa May was trying her best to secure a deal and says the backstop provided some degree of certainty for the border region and both jurisdictions.I think the deal we were getting for the North and the southern part of Ireland was meant to be the bees knees but nobody would back her.” The young farmer, whose older brother is Cavan footballer Gearoid McKiernan, is also very worried about the prospects of tax hikes on milk exports eating into their profits. He added: “Farming is a tough game. Tarfs would be the biggest [Brexit] worry, especially in the dairy industry. “Our dairy exports [in Ireland] are worth over €million and I think about €million of that is exported to the UK. “If there’s tarfs on all that, what way is it going to go ” Breffni explained how most of their income comes from dairy farming, with  cows on their farm. He said they buy a lot of their feed from cross-border business Lakelands, adding: “We make our own silage and we buy in the meal and fertiliser. Most of the fertiliser that comes here is probably from Northern companies.

title: irish couple swap four hour
story: NewsCouple swap four-hour city commute for abandoned islandLesley Kehoe, , and Gordon Bond, , grew tired of their city le and decided to relocate to An Blascoad Mor, the largest part of The Great Blasket IslandsShareByLata Yedroudj:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsLesley Kehoe and Gordon Bond ditched the city le for remote island living"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Irish couple have ditched city living and relocated to an abandoned island off the coast of Co Kerry - but say they are loving every minute of it. Lesley Kehoe, , and Gordon Bond, , are said to be the only inhabitants at An Blascaod Mor, the largest part of The Great Blasket Islands, located off the coast of Co Kerry. Tired of spending four hours commuting from Kildare to the Dublin everyday, the couple made the le-changing decision to move island which has been abandoned since .Lesley told the Irish Sunday Mirror : “I have always been interested in the Great Blasket Islands - I wrote my thesis about their heritage.“As part of my research Gordon and I went out there and we stayed in one of the cottages.“We just fell in love with the place and in January I saw a Facebook post advertising a job looking after the hostel there.“I had been working in the heritage sector at a Seamus Heaney exhibition and Gordon was in the civil service at the time. “I loved my work but we both wanted a bit of a change and a break from our routine so we decided to go for it and  days later we got the job.”  The island has no electricity or hot water, and they have to rely on gas to cook their food. Lesley added: “There’s a wind turbine which powers a socket so we have one socket for the whole place – it wouldn’t be powerful enough to run a hoover or anything but it can charge my phone. “I can take bookings for the hostel on that and send in our shopping lists – we couldn’t do without it. “I still walk into a room sometimes and think, ‘It’s very dark in here’ and go to turn on the light, then remember I can’t. “The lack of electricity hasn’t actually bothered me that much but it did take me a while to get used to not having hot water. “I said I was going to heat up water every day, that I’d never have a cold shower – but to be honest you’d be upstairs and dressed by the time you’d have the water heated in the kettle so I just decided to brave it.”The island was abandoned in  as emergency services had dficulty accessing the mainland in times of bad weather . Lesley said: You just have to be prepared and hope that nothing goes wrong. “Sometimes we are cut off from the mainland for three or four days. “We just have to be mindful of that and not take any chances, we take it easy when we’re lting chairs and tables in the house and things like that.” The couple, who supervise a hostel on the island, said they are never lonely because they always have visitors. Lesley said: “We can have up to  people in the accommodation, boats come out from Dingle, Bantry and Dunquin. “Thenthe weather is bad it’s just us but that’s actually our favourite time. All you can hear is the beach and the waves. That’s when we really get to appreciate the island and landscape and what the islanders would have went through when they were living here.”

title: our baby could been saved
story: NewsOur baby could have been saved with a simple test - instead we watched her dieWARNING - UPSETTING CONTENT: Lyndsey Smitherman didnt get to hold her baby girl Sophie until she had died of Parvovirus B, also known as slapped cheek syndromeShareByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsSophie Carly Hope in intensive care - this was the first time her parents saw her properly "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving mum has described the heartbreaking two days she spent with her baby girl before she watched her die. Sophie Carly Hope Smitherman was born at .pm on December , . Her parents Lyndsey and Sam Smitherman heard her cry twice before she was rushed out of the room and taken to intensive care where she lived for less than  hours. The first time Lyndsey was able to hold her little girl was after she had died. She said it felt like apossomeone had torn her heart in halfapos. Sophieaposs mum and dad had just watched doctors desperately perform CPR on their tiny daughter but eventually there was nothing more that could be done. She had struggled to breathe immediately after birth and her platelets had not formed properly meaning she had been bleeding. She had a total of  blood transfusions in the  hours she was alive, her mum said. Her siblings Jack-James, six, Annabelle-Violet, five, and Meadow, four, tragically never got to meet their baby sister.    Lyndsey turned  on Motheraposs Day this year, but she said it killed me inside. The mum-of-four told how results from an autopsy two months after Sophieaposs death on .pm on the December , , revealed she had died of Parvovirus B. Parvovirus B is a virus that commonly infects children and is not routinely tested for during pregnancy. Lyndsey claims she was told by doctors thatshe had been tested for it during pregnancy, her baby could have been saved with a blood transfusion while still in the womb. The mum is now bravely sharing her story to raise awareness of the virus, in the hope that other pregnant women will become aware of it and consider requesting a test. Lyndsey says she does not want anyone  to suffer like they have had to.    Speaking to Mirror, Lyndsey, from Kent, described the heartbreaking moment her baby girl passed away as doctors performed CPR. She said: We kept on saying aposyou can make it, you can do it Sophie.apos I sort of zoned out and felt like it was not me in the room. They said aposwe are doing everything we can for herapos and carried on for a while longer. But then they came over and said aposwe have got to stopapos. It was like someone tore my heart in half and I wanted to collapse to the floor because I was in so much pain.  But I couldnapost collapse to the floor because no one would have been able to pick me up because of the pain. As soon as she passed away they said we could hold her. Within seconds I had her in my arms and it was the first time I held her. It was amazing to be able to feel her but hard knowing that she was not actually there.    The school supervisor added: The Parvovirus B had got to her so much it was shutting everything down. The virus was in her heart, so the whole body went into shut down. I wish I had been tested for it because then I would still have her here. Lyndsey and husband Sam, , found out in May last year they were expecting another baby. The mum said it was just like any of her other pregnancies, she was sailing through it, going to her scans, and everything seemed fine. But on Sunday December  when Lyndsey went to bed things werenapost quite right. There was not a lot of movement, she described. All my girls, when Iaposve been pregnant, have kicked me to pieces. Sophie would come up between me and Sam when he used to lie on my belly, but that evening she didnapost do it.  When Lyndsey woke up the following morning she said things had not got any better as she tried to get her moving. She phoned the hospital and explained how she felt reduced movement and was advised to go in to be checked out and monitored. At that point she was nearing the  week mark. When she went into hospital for tests, Lyndsey said medics told her aposwe need to get her out as soon asapos. Theyaposd picked up her heart rate was not great and it was like she was sleepy inside, Lyndsey said. They broke my waters to try and get everything started and my contractions began pretty quickly. But doctors could see she was not getting her breath back quickly enough so they suggested an emergency c-section. We wanted to be safe so we went for it. Lyndsey said doctors were reassuring about the cesarean and she and Sam felt quite relaxed as the procedure for Jack-Jamesapos birth had been OK. Sophie was born at .pm on December , , but she was immediately whisked away by medical staff. As soon as she was born, we heard her cry twice and then she was taken away from us to help her to breathe, Lyndsey told. Just as they said to Sam aposdo you want to come over and see her,apos they rushed her out of the room and said she needed to get a bit of help. We didnapost get told anything until we went into the recovery room.  Lyndsey said as it approached midnight a doctor came to show them a picture of their daughter and explained she was in intensive care having trouble with her lungs and was jaundiced. Other people were coming in the room with their babies, but I didnapost have my baby Lyndsey said, explaining she and Sam still hadnapost met their precious daughter properly in person. In the picture she had looked perfect, she was still our daughter. But it was heartbreaking not being able to see her. It was about .am on December  by the time they were allowed to see her. Before they took her, they brought her to us but it was only for five minutes, then they rushed her out, Lyndsey said. I wanted it to last longer, she said, but her baby needed a blood transfusion. We didnapost even get to touch her as she was in an incubator. The parents were warned Sophie was not forming her platelets which was causing her to bleed. We were told sheaposd need to be transferred to another hospital but I couldnapost go with her and had to wait until .am until the ambulance took me, Lyndsey said. Sam had to drive as they wouldnapost let him in the ambulance. When they got to the second hospital, little Sophie was having further scans. It was .am when they got to see her again. She was in her little incubator and had wires coming out everywhere, Lyndsey said. She had lots of dferent machines around her and a blue light on her for jaundice. Her skin was really shiny and she was very bloated because she was being pumped with dferent things. She couldnapost breath, she was having blood transfusions every hour. I loved the fact I was able to be there with her, but at the same time I was thinking aposshe has so much going onapos.  Lyndsey still tried so stay positive, and believed her daughter would be fine and that she was in the best place. I just wanted to spend all the time with her, she told. They allowed us to sit there and touch her. We were able to stick our hand through the holeand touch her hand. But after a little while of holding her, her stats dropped and we had to move. We werenapost allowed to touch our own daughter. Doctors were constantly at her side. At around .pm, Sophie had a terrying setback as she suffered a cardiac arrest. The parents were not present at the time and were told by doctors what had happened after they had aposbrought her backapos. They warned that aposthings werenapost brilliantapos. I was shocked and thought aposwhatanything had happened to her,apos Lyndsey told. But after they said they brought her back I felt positive she would be OK and she would pull through. I thoughtsheaposd got through that, she will get through this, little fighter.  Lyndseyaposs parents had brought the other kids to the hospital after school, but they were not allowed to see their new sister as she was too ill. Late that night, Lyndsey and Sam were askedthey had thought about christening their daughter. Sam asked, aposdoes that mean she is not going to pull through,apos but they wouldnapost answer that question, Lyndsey said. I kept thinking aposshe is my little girl, she will make it throughapos. Sophie was christened at am on December  with a priest coming into the hospital for the ceremony. By .am they were taken aside by a doctor who explained aposthings werenapost looking greatapos. He said only half of her heart was doing the work, Lyndsey said. He said aposshe may not make itapos andshe did things wouldnapost be brilliant for her. That made us feel really sick. We asked my parents to get the kids out of school early so they could come and see her before anything happened. The kids didnapost get to meet her at all. At . Lyndsey and Sam were back in ICU with their daughter but had to witness doctors performing CPR on her, at barely two days old. It was hard, very hard, it made me feel really, really low, Lyndsey said. She added: My parents had just arrived with the other kids, they were waiting outside the door when she passed away. Sam was there with me the whole time, he never left my side. All we left the hospital with was a memory box with a few things of hers - her little hat that held the tubes in place, little sunglasses to cover her eyes from the blue light. Lyndsey said two months later, following an autopsy, they found out their daughter had died of Parvovirus B, also known as aposslapped cheekapos. The NHS says:Parvovirus B is a virus that commonly infects children. It is usually transmitted by coughing and sneezing and hand washing is important in helping to prevent spread. For most healthy people, Parvovirus B causes a mild, self-limiting illness which is followed by le-long immunity. Pregnant women are not routinely screened for past Parvovirus B infection as there is no vaccine or preventative treatment available. The exact number of Parvovirus B infections in the UK is not known as the virus does not always show symptoms, and the diagnosis can only be confirmed by blood test. In women who are not immune, infection in the first  weeks of pregnancy can lead to serious problems for your baby before it is born.This would usually happen three to five weeks after the onset of maternal infection, but can be later. The greatest period of risk to the baby is between four to  weeks. Infection during this time can sometimes lead to serious complications such as fetal anaemia and sometimes fetal loss .There is a five – ten per cent risk of fetal losswomen develop this infection in the second trimester. Infection in the first month of pregnancy is not thought to carry any risk. Most babies will not be infected or affected by the virus. For more information, click here.

story: NewsSuicidal student jumped off building after crisis team told her sound, you can goSophie Sutton, who survived the fall from the top of University Hospital Aintrees car park, in Liverpool, said medics told her sound you can go despite her desperate warnings about her mental healthShareByJonathan HumphriesPippa Allen-Kinross:,  AUG NewsSophie feels like she wasnt taken seriously by hospital staff "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA student tried to leap to her death from a hospital car park after being discharged in the middle of the night by mental health workers she claims she had warned she was suicidal. Sophie Sutton, , was admitted to University Hospital Aintree in Liverpool on May  last year after taking an overdose, but says she was told to go home by medics despite her warnings that she wanted to jump.The former Liverpool John Moores University Student was left in agonising pain and needing surgery after shattering both her legs in the leap from the top of the multi-storey car park.She has been diagnosed with Emotional Unstable Personality Disorder and depression.    Sophie, from West Derby, told the Liverpool Echo that she had been struggling with low-mood, anxiety and suicidal thoughts. She said the jump was a genuine attempt to end her le but she did not feel that the mental health team took her seriously, despite a previous attempt to jump from the same car park. My heart was racing and I felt determined. I was scared at the same time. As I let go I felt instant regret and wanted to go back, but obviously couldnapost, she said. Sophie said she was taken to Aintree Hospital on May  by a relative after taking an overdose, and was checked over before being seen by the mental health team just after midnight.She said: There were two members of the crisis team I saw.We went to a room in AE majors and they asked me why I took the overdose, but at the time I was fixated on what I was doing to do [jump] but I was scared at the same time, so I told them I wanted to jump. They didnapost know how to respond. I donapost think they believed my intentions were real.   After I said I couldnapost get home and had no money, one member said apossound, you can go, find something to do for a few hours or you can walk homeapos so I felt judged and not taken seriously.Then I picked myself up and ran out. Sophieaposs case was one of a series of troubling incidents identied in a review into problems at Mersey Care NHS Foundation Trust, which runs the cityaposs mental health services.The thematic review action plan said some mental health practitioners at the trust, particularly those in hospital settings, were working with gaps in their knowledge.The report mentioned another woman who had thrown herself from the building after being admitted following an overdose. Since itaposs publication, a man in his s fell from the second floor after being sectioned.Sophie, who hopes to work as a mental health nurse, said she would have been seen as high risk after a similar suicide attempt around three months before the fall, when she took an overdose while an inpatient at Clock View Hospital in Walton. She was also taken to Aintree on that occasion and managed to make her way to the top floor of the car park building, but was stopped from jumping by police officers.Despite the warning signs, Sophie said she felt as though the crisis team did not take her intentions seriously, which only strengthened her intention to jump.She said: It was adrenaline at first but then I just got this huge, horrible pain in both legs, and I couldnapost feel my feet. I went back to Aintree in an ambulance and they gave me gas and air and ketamine. Sophie says the tibia and fibula in both legs were broken, and to make matters worse she developed a pulmonary embolism - a blood clot which travelled to her lung.She had surgery to replace metal rods in her legs and remained in hospital for two weeks, before spending another two weeks in a rehabilitation centre.

title: widows online lover kevin cruel
story: NewsWidows online lover Kevin was actually six fraudsters who stole £k savingsDi Pogson, , got back into dating after losing her husband nearly  years - but Kevin span web of lies from vets bills to being stuck abroad with an unusable debit cardShareCommentsByAbigail OLearyErin Cardf:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsDi believed she had found love with Kevin - before the cruel plot began to unravel "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA widowaposs online lover aposKevinapos actually turned out to be a cruel con by a gang of fraudsters who duped her out of £,. Di Pogson, , decided to get back into dating after losing her husband, Ian, of nearly  years suddenly in July . After years of grieving, Di decided to join a dating site in late , where she was swept off her feet by a jet-setting businessman called Kevin Thompson. He purported to be a fellow widower in his fties based in London - and Di felt an instant connection with him. Believing he understood the pain of losing a cherished partner, as they exchanged messages and spoke on the phone, they grew closer until Di, of Holmfirth, West Yorkshire, genuinely believed she had found love. But, once he had gained her trust, ‘Kevin’ began to ask her for money, fabricating all sorts of reasons from having a vetaposs bill to pay to being stuck abroad with an unusable debit card to wheedle cash from her. Convinced he was genuine and would repay her, Di agreed – until his web of lies began to unravel with alarming consequences.    The police became involved - discovering that Kevin Thompson was a  profile, set up by a gang consisting of ringleaders Yaw Sarpong, , Nicholas Adade,  and Eric Ocansey, , and more peripheral members Obed Addo, , and Daniel Keh, . Speaking out after the con artists were convicted for their crimes at Guildford Crown Court, Di now wants to raise awareness of dating scams to protect other vulnerable people from falling foul of them. She said: “For a long time, I felt so stupid. I’m a grown woman – how on earth had I been conned like this  People may read this and think it would never happen to them, but until youaposve been in this situation, you donapost know. “But aposKevinapos truly led me to believe that he loved me, that we’d be together. I was in a vulnerable state then, having lost Ian, and I wanted and needed to be loved. “Whenever I did start asking questions, he would turn it round on me and make me feel guilty. It was incredibly manipulative. “I can’t go back and undo anything though, and I refuse to let this eat me up, or they win all over again. Now, I just want to help other people and to warn them to be wary online.” Di, who is retired, was approaching her th wedding anniversary when Ian suddenly became unwell, developing dficulty walking. He was taken to hospital and given a CT scan, which initially appeared fine – only for him to rapidly decline just hours later.    She recalled: “He had the scan, and I saw him that evening. I left the hospital at about pm on July  and he seemed relatively fine. “Then, my phone rang when I was back home at about pm. It was someone from the hospital telling me to come back. “By the time I got there, Ian was dead. He’d died of an undetected embolism, which is when the arteries get blocked by something like a blood clot or air bubble. “It was horrendous. The scan being fine had almost lulled me into a  sense of security.” In October , Di began to think about companionship and how much she missed it. She added: “It wasn’t necessarily about relationships. I just wanted a friend – someone to go for meals or to the cinema with.” So, she joined an online dating site and, before long, she came across the profile of Kevin Thompson, who presented himself as a well-to-do businessman. “He wasn’t what I’d call drop dead gorgeous, but he seemed like a nice, normal guy,” she said. “He told me he had a daughter, and that he had also been widowed when his we died very suddenly. “I felt comfortable opening up to him and telling him about Ian, and the memories we had.    “He would tell me about all the places he’d been with his we, and say he wanted to take me too. He sent me all these photos of him on holiday, and I even spoke to him on the phone. “He was well-spoken and sounded completely normal – there was nothing to ring any alarm bells.” After a couple of weeks of talking, Di received a message from Kevin, claiming to have an emergency with his pet dog. She explained: “He said he was stuck abroad and that his card wouldn’t work, but that he needed £ for an emergency vetaposs bill, as his dog was very sick. “I’m an animal lover myself, and he made me feel so guilty. In the back of my mind, I thought, ‘Would a vet really demand money up front like that ’ “But he was so convincing, and every question I had, he came up with a plausible answer.” Convinced she was helping save the le of an innocent animal, Di transferred the cash. And, before long, more requests came through, with Kevin telling ious hoods, each time guilt tripping her into helping. His sob stories included everything from being overseas on a business trip with a blocked card, to having to pay government taxes related to his business so he could fly back to the UK.    “Each time, the amount was around £,, said Di. Before I ever spoke to Kevin, I’d had a couple of spam messages from people asking for money, and each time, I saw them coming a mile off. “If only Iaposd been as astute this time, as I do look back and feel stupid that I fell for his con. “He always had an answer, though, and he would play a lot on my guilt and self-doubt. If I questioned too much, I’d get, ‘Why don’t you trust me ’ or ‘You can’t possibly love meyou aren’t helping.’ “He made promise after promise to pay me back, too, and the way he had presented himself, he seemed like he would be able to. By the end, it felt like I had to keep giving over moneyI ever wanted to see a penny of it back – almost like I had to keep him on side until we met in person. Also, the picture Kevin painted of his glamorous le made it seem asa few thousand pounds meant nothing to him - which Di found made it even harder to say no. “He’d talk about his flash lestyle, how he had a Ferrari and spent summers in Italy. He told me it was degrading that he even had to ask for money, she said. “He even said he had written me a cheque for £,, which is more than I lent him, to thank me.” As Di fell deeper and deeper under Kevin’s manipulative spell, he also convinced her that he was in love with her, to the point where she genuinely believed they were in a trusting relationship.    She added: “He led me to believe we’d be together and have this idyllic le. We’d talk on the phone and he’d say he loved hearing my voice, and would ask when my birthday was, so he could send a present. “He even sent me flowers – some red roses – and would tell me he was going to get me a diamond ring. “He said he loved me, and I said it back. Now, I don’t think I did, but at the time, I genuinely believed I could.” But the illusion of romance and grandeur Kevin had created was swtly shattered in December , when Di came down to London, believing she was going to finally meet him in person. In the weeks prior to this, nagging doubts had been mounting in her mind, but the idea of finally seeing him in the flesh – and the promise he would have a cheque for her – alleviated her suspicions. The plan had been for him to meet her at her hotel near Marble Arch in the centre of the city – but he never came. She recalled: “He seemed really excited to meet me. He’d apparently been to China on business, and was flying in that day. He even asked me to meet him at the airport, so we’d have longer together. “In the end, we agreed to meet at my hotel. I sat in the foyer, waiting and waiting, but he never came. “It was horrendous, I felt like such an idiot. Eventually, I lost my temper and left an angry voicemail. “I didn’t hear back until the next morning. He said he’d been on a delayed flight then fallen asleep at home, but had to go straight back to China as something had gone wrong. “He even turned the voicemail back on me, calling me heartless and saying he couldn’t believe I would speak to him like that.” Di then askedshe could at least meet him to get the cheque he had promised – but yet again, he had an answer, claiming he was already back at the airport and didn’t have it with him to post.    She did have his address, but he told her she wouldn’t be able to get into the property to retrieve her money. By that point, there was no doubt in her mind that something was wrong. What’s more, she was in financial dire straits, having given him a staggering £, – most of which came from a loan she had taken out, on his advice, to help ease her debts. “Kevin knew about the loan – he was the one who suggested it, as I’d been struggling with maxed out credit cards and being overdrawn,” she said. “He said it would be a way to clear all of that and keep myself afloat. But he took every penny.” Shortly after their doomed meeting, Kevin tried one more time to get money out of Di, telling her that once again he was stuck abroad, and would not be able to get home for Christmas. She continued: “He said his daughter would be alone, and that I was abandoning him to spend Christmas by himself. “By then, I knew something was wrong anyway – but there was also no money left to give. I couldn’t have helped himI’d wanted to.” Shockingly, as soon as Di told Kevin she didnapost have a penny to give him, he disappeared, never to message her again. But she was not prepared to let him get away with what he had done and reported him to police. Officers then spent years tirelessly building their case, combing through messages, and eventually unmasking the gang behind the fake profile.    It emerged there was also another victim, who had been conned out of £,. “One of the hardest parts was admitting to myself just how much they had taken,” said Di. “Going through the messages brought it all back – I felt so stupid. “Now, I can see that they were written by dferent people. You can tell by spelling mistakes. But at the time, I was convinced I had found love.” During their investigations, police also found that the address Kevin had given to Di was , registered to a complete stranger. Finally, in July , the gang appeared at Guildford Crown Court to answer for their crimes. There, a jury found Yaw Sarpong, of Hampshire, guilty of conspiracy to commit fraud by  representation, and he was jailed for  months. His associates Nicholas Adade Adu, of Stoke on Trent, Staffs., and Eric Ocansey, of Birmingham, pleaded guilty to the same charge. Adu was jailed for three years and seven months, while Ocansey was jailed for two years – both also receiving  months for money laundering, to run concurrently. Obed Addo, from Roehampton, was jailed for  months for money laundering, while Daniel Keh, of Enfield, north west London, was jailed for  months for converting criminal property and supplying articles to be used in fraud, plus six months for money laundering to run concurrently. Now, Di is looking ahead to rebuilding her le, and is happily in a new relationship after meeting her current partner, who she does not wish to name, online  months ago. She said: “I was wary to get back online, but I now know thatsomebody is making excuses and putting off meeting you in person, it’s not right. Either they are messing you around – or something more.

New York Cityaposs Chief Medical Examiner said the determination is still pending the day after the paedophile billionaire was found in his cell. It comes as the New York Post claimed a source said there was no surveillance footage of the moment the former financier died. According to the paper, cameras are focused on the areas outside cells at the politan Correctional Center but not inside. Chief Medical Examiner Barbara Sampson said in a statement: The Medical Examineraposs determination is pending further information at this time.    At the request of those representing the decedent, and with the awareness of the federal prosecutor, I allowed a private pathologistto observe the autopsy examination. This is routine practice. It was revealed previously how Epstein had been placed on suicide watch after he was found with injuries to his neck on July . However, he had recently been taken off in a decision that has reportedly baffled former wardens. A source told Reuters that two jail guards are required to make separate checks on all prisoners every  minutes.  However, that procedure was not followed in the hours before Epstein was found in his cell. A prison official told the New York Times one of the guards was working for his fth straight day of overtime, while the second corrections officer had been forced to work overtime as well. Other sources old the Daily Mail that Epstein had told prison guards and fellow inmates that he believed someone had tried to kill him. The insider also claimed he seemed to be in good spirits.    There was no indication that he might try to take his own le, the source said. From what I saw, he was finally starting to adjust to prison. I think he was comforted by the rigidity of his new le. For years Epstein, who never married and had no children, had been accused of sexually abusing girls and young women. Following his arrest on July , he had pleaded not guilty to charges of sex trafficking involving dozens of underage girls as young as , from at least  to . He was accused of recruiting underage women to engage in sex acts with him, sometimes over a period of years while paying the women for each encounter.

title: bmw driver sparks parents wrath
story: NewsBMW driver sparks parents wrath after wedging child under massive flat screen TVOne person summed it up as, "When you drive a BMW, but can’t afford the  delivery"ShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  AUG NewsAt first its easy to miss it "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Electrical goods are often pain in the backside to transport.Theyaposre bulky and pricey, meaning they take up loads of space - but you also have to handle them carefully.Still, at least most retailers now offer delivery - itaposs just a shame one driver chose to not opt for this.Instead, they chose to pop their new flat screen in the back of the car. Nothing wrong with this, in theory - except a photo of the BMW driver is now circulating online because of one almost-hidden detail. Also in the back is a small child, who had been almost completely concealed by the box. When you drive a BMW, but canapost afford the  delivery, the original post read.   It took other members of the Facebook page Downsht  a little while to see what was meant by the post, until someone  cleared the confusion up and pointed out that a child could be seen peeping from under the box.:Heroes, the lot of you. Look under the TV, Downsht captioned the post yesterday. This is the kind of person who needs a reminder that their kid is in the car, one person fumed.

title: cleaning mistakes could making you
story: NewsCleaning mistakes that could be making you ill - and they can be very dangerousMost of us spent a lot more time than we would like scrubbing, sweeping and dusting, so its important to know what all those chemicals are doing to our insidesShareCommentsByPoppy Danby:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsIts really important to know whats safe "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore and more of us are learning to love cleaning thanks to Mrs Hinch and other social media stars who have somehow made dish cloths and disinfectant cool. But mopping, sweeping and dusting can all have a negative effect on our health. And, in some cases, cleaning can even make us ill. We spoke to cleaning expert Ralitsa Prodanova from home cleaning firm Fantastic Services about the top  mistakes you could be making around your home and the best way to keep your pad spick and span. Scrubbing black mould Nobody wants their house to get mouldy, but scrubbing spores can be extremely hazardous. Ralitsa says: “Black mould, caused by damp, is unsightly and itaposs tempting to try and scrub it away. But doing so could cause respiratory problems – and even hallucinations. “Black mould that grows on damp walls can often be highly toxic. These living, organic moulds can send spores into the air – which spread like a virus.”    The most common type of mould can cause respiratory problems, skin inflammation, tiredness and nausea. Whereas moulds such as “rye ergot” can even cause hallucinations. To get rid of mould safely, Ralitsa, advises: “Always wear a protective mask, rubber gloves and safety glasses. “The most effective way of combatting mould is to pour bleach into a spraying bottle, before covering mouldy areas and letting the bleach get to work for  minutes. Open all windows to allow any toxic fumes to escape and wipe and rinse the area.” Skipping the gym From dumbbells to yoga mats, many people have some form of fitness equipment lying around at home. But how often do they get thoroughly scrubbed  Ralitsa, says: “There have been lots of studies into the bugs that lurk on workout equipment. And, often, gym equipment carries more germs than toilets – including those which can cause boils, eczma, acne and rosacea – aw well as the dreaded superbug, MRSA. “Gym equipment might get missing in your cleaning routine but it needs to be wiped and disinfected regularly.” Chemical reactions When youaposre using multiple cleaning products you need to be careful not to mix them.    Ralitsa, says: “Household cleaning chemicals are often hazardous. But they become even more dangerous when mixed. “The key thing to watch out for is mixing bleach with other substances. Bleach and any ammonia-based cleaners is a no-no, as it can potentially create a toxic gas that could even prove deadly in some circumstances. Meanwhile, bleach and vinegar can also release a gas that can attack your airways.” Making your bed Forget everything your mother told you, as making your bed can actually be bad for your health. Ralista, explains: “You should actually stop making your bed in the morning, as soon as you wake up. Instead, you should throw the duvet off the bed and let your mattress breathe. “Dust mites love warmth and humidity, which is why they love your bed.   “The problem is that their microscopic faeces can trigger reactions, including asthma and eczema , as well as sneezing, a runny nose, red eyes, itching, tightness in the chest and shortness of breath.“Butyou leave your bed unmade every morning – exposing your bed to cold air – the miles will simply dehydrate and die. “Then itaposs just a case of washing bedding weekly in hot temperatures while frequently dusting and vacuuming, too.” Not cleaning the vacuum Most of us only empty our hoovers when they are full. But it needs to be done on a regular basis. Ralitsa explains: “The brushes and the insides of vacuums essentially act as a mobile germ factory.  “Bacteria and germs are festering and breeding on the inside, multiplying rapidly. And, there has been research to suggest that  per cent of all vacuum cleaners actually harbour the bug, E. coli. “Iaposd advise homeowners to empty their vacuum on a much more regular basis and to give it a good wipe and disinfection after every use, too.” Forgetting to seal the deal Itaposs incredibly close to all our food – but the fridge seal is often overlooked in the cleaning process. Ralitsa says: “Fridge door seals typically have lots of folds and crevices, where it pushes against the sides of the unit in order to form a tight seal. But these crevices are food residue traps and bugs can sit there, undetected, for years. “It can also trap mould, which gets released every time you close and open the door and which can lead to allergies.” Have you got a story to share  Email webfeatures@trinitymirror.    Not throwing the towel in Tea towels often get used multiple times before theyaposre tossed into the washing machine. But you should actually be changing them every single day. Ralitsa says: “Tea towels are often moist and warm from previous use – allowing for bacteria to multiply rapidly. “Iaposd recommend you either replace them every day with clean, dry ones. Or wash them at the end of each day, so they are ready for use again the next morning.” And Ralitsa suggests performing the same routine for our oven gloves too. Putting the lid down Your bathroom might be sparkling after a good clean, but youaposll instantly undo all your hard workyou leave the lid of your toilet up when you flush. “Every time you flush your toilet, poo particles are flung into the air,” says Ralitsa. “These bio-aerosols can be extremely harmful – and the airborne water droplets are often contaminated with viruses and bacteria.”

title: dundees game of two halves leaves mcpake with decisions to make for ayr
story: Dundee welcome Ayr United to Dens Park this weekend looking for victory after kicking off the Championship campaign with a draw at Dunfermline.Saturday will be the Dark Blues fans’ first chance to get use out of their season tickets but what kind of Dundee side are they likely to see run out in the first home league match of the season Manager James McPake is the first to admit the first-half performance at East End Park was well below expectations at the club.With that in mind it’s highly unlikely he’ll choose the same unchanged side for the third match in a row.Half-time subs Declan McDaid and Josh Todd impressed from the bench on Friday night as Dundee came from two goals behind to draw - and will come into the manager’s thinking this weekend.McPake said: “I’ve watched it back and we weren’t good enough in the first half. We know that as a team.“But you ask for a reaction and you ask for character – that was there in abundance in the second half.“I thought the two boys, McDaid and Todd, coming on did really well and we looked more of a threat.“Looking back at the game now it was a game of two halves — a cliche I know — but it probably ended up a fair result.“Near the end I thought we might nick it, too.“Both McDaid and Todd have been in the mix. I like both of them, and Jamie Ness is back in the mix now, too.“It’s healthy we have him back and healthy we have those two pushing for places. That adds to the squad.”So, what are the possibilities for the Dens gaffer against Ian McCall’s Honest Men Despite an error for the second goal at Dunfermline, Jack Hamilton is the undisputed No  goalie at the club and will almost certainly retain his spot ahead of second-choice Calum Ferrie.After seeing the three-man backline perform well in a commanding performance against Inverness in the Betfred Cup the match previous, it’s clear the same line-up didn’t work at Dunfermline.Every game is dferent but should McPake switch to a back four, that’ll obviously see one centre-half drop out.The knock picked up by skipper Josh Meekings and his injury history make him favourite to miss out.Andrew Davies is nowhere near match fitness so that leaves Jordon Forster and Jordan McGhee as central defenders for this one.At full-back, Jordan Marshall did OK and will likely continue, as will Cammy Kerr on the right, though he didn’t have his best night at East End Park.A shake-up in defence would bring another midfielder into play and with McDaid, Todd and Ness all banging on the door for a starting spot, McPake has decisions to make. Young Finn Robertson has been excellent so far this campaign but his youthfulness may see him replaced by the more experienced Ness for this one.Paul McGowan and Shaun Byrne are key players but,Dundee go to a -- that’s likely to see one miss out – or McGowan moved further upfield.On the wings, McDaid and Todd may have done enough to earn their starting spurs.Danny Johnson’s three goals in two matches make him almost certain to start. Less certain is Andrew Nelson’s place after he was replaced at half-time on Friday, however.Injury and illness have hampered Craig Curran lately, though he is expected to be fit for Saturday.McGowan in behind Johnson could be McPake’s pick for this big early-season clash.

title: aberdeen lose 1 0 to st mirren in premiership
story: Aberdeen will go into Thursday#s Europa League third qualying roundleg against Rijeka on the back of a Premiership loss to St Mirren.After their - defeat in Croatia, the Reds were looking to get back to winning ways, but Ilkay Durmus# early goal in Paisley denied them.Derek McInnes’ team never really got their attack going and were found to be vulnerable on the break in damp conditions.The rampant optimism of a week ago, after they’d beaten Georgians Chikhura Sachkhere and then Hearts at Pittodrie, has been dimmed, and they’ll need to improve across the board to have any chance of overturning the Croatian Cup winners’ - first leg lead and keep their hopes of the Euro group stage alive.McInnes made four changes from the team which lost - to Rijeka.Shay Logan, who handed Rijeka a penalty by pulling back Luka Capan, was dropped for new Bristol City loanee Zak Vyner, who made his first appearance.With one eye on Thursday’s , McInnes freshened up the attack with Scott Wright, Connor McLennan and league debutant Curtis Main in for Jon Gallagher, Niall McGinn and Sam Cosgrove – although there were questions marks as to whether Cosgrove’s absence was due to muscle tightness.St Mirren had the first chance to threaten on  minutes from a free-kick after Greg Leigh  bundled Paul McGinn to the deck on the right of the box.Durmus’ initial left-footed effort hit Funso Ojo in the wall, before Tony Andreu’s tame effort from  yards was caught easily by Joe Lewis.However, the home side opened the scoring on  minutes.Greg Leigh got caught out of position after a poor clearing header, with McGinn setting Kyle Magennis free down the right.He squared to the Durmus, who broke into the area and finished into the bottom right corner.It could’ve been two on  minutes. Calum Waters cross from the left headed over by Durmus.Main blazed a shot over from outside the area with  minutes played, having shrugged Gary Mackenzie off in the visitors’ first effort.The Dons interchanging midfield four of Wright, Ryan Hedges, Lewis Ferguson and McLennan wasn’t quite clicking for all their energy, with the man in possession being crowded out.Up the other end, big striker Jon Obika looked a real handful, with his pace, strength and aggression occupying Andy Considine and Scott McKenna.However, Hedges did find space to fire into Vaclav Hladky’s hands from  yards on  minutes, before Ferguson shot miles wide with a free-kick from  yards.Despite building a bit of pressure towards the end of the period, no more real chances materialised.Conversely, an  Andreu free-kick and Durmus overhead kick could’ve extended Saints’ lead, but were both caught by Lewis.Soon after play restarted, Main turned well with the ball and almost found the top left corner from range.On  minutes, Vyner got forward and delivered a pinpoint cross on to Ferguson’s head, and Hladky tipped over the bar.Three minutes later, the keeper threw himself on a deflected McLennan strike. However, he appeared to lt his hands from the ball, which Main stole and rolled into the net.Referee Steven McLean didn’t allow the equaliser – which would’ve been contentious – to stand.But it was a decent spell for Aberdeen, with Hladky punching a whipped Hedges free-kick clear soon after, before Sean McLoughlin looked to handle another of the attacker’s deliveries into the middle.Vyner was booked for protesting too vocerously for a penalty.Gaffer McInnes sent the rested Niall McGinn and Jon Gallagher on for McLennan and Wright in an attempt to force the issues for the Reds.But, on  minutes, St Mirren could’ve scored again, but Andreu somehow flicked Paul McGinn’s cross past the post.Ryan Flynn then went close with  minutes to go, ghosting inside, but shooting straight at Considine as he tried to find the inside of the front post.Kyle McAllister was next to try for the home side, and his long-range effort narrowly missed the top left corner.James Wilson was sent on for the Dons as they threw everything at the quick-countering Buddies to try and level it.The big chance of a frantic finish fell to substitute McGinn, from Considine’s cross, but he struck the outside of the post on the angle at the death.

title: aberdeen man climbs 50 munros in 150 days to raise cash charlie house
story: An Aberdeen man who challenged himself to climb  Munros in only  days has completed his goal.Bruce Russell, director at recruitment business Right People, is a keen hillwalker and often tackles around  to  Munros a year.Alongside his we Clare for many of the treks, he took on the gruelling task – raising more than £, for children’s charity Charlie House in the process.Charlie House supports children and young people with complex disabilities and or le-limiting conditions.He also often took along its mascot Charlie Dog for the journey.Bruce said: “This was a much bigger challenge than I expected but the thought of those who would benefit kept me going.“It’s such a worthwhile cause, I’m delighted I could contribute. After climbing Munros right across Scotland, it was nice to finish up relatively close to home.“I was delighted to complete the challenge at the weekend and would like to thank everyone who has supported me.”Since beginning the challenge at the end of March, he has walked  miles – a total ascent of ,m. This is the equivalent of climbing Mount Everest – which is ,m – more than three times.Kirsty Walker, fundraising co-ordinator at Charlie House, said: “What a fantastic achievement. We can’t thank Bruce enough for what he has done.“He’s basically devoted much of his free time over the past four months to support our appeal to raise £ million to build a specialist support centre. His contribution will make a huge dference to the lives of many children and young people in the north-east of Scotland.”The money raised will go towards Charlie House’s Big Build Appeal, which was launched in November last year.It aims to raise £m to build a new specialist support centre set in four acres of ground at Woodend Hospital.A range of dferent facilities will be on offer to benefit youngsters and their families.These include a spa pool, teen den, Star room for end-of-le care and bereavement, sensory gardens, and more. Similar facilities can currently only be accessed in Kinross, more than  miles away, which aren’t available for many north-east families.There will also be dedicated office facilities for Charlie House employees.Donations to Bruce’s fundraiser can still be made online at www.justgiving  fundraising bruce-russell

title: letters week 24
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UK’s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact people’s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition – and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotland’s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotland’s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.
